\section{Introduction}
In this paper we focus on measures defined on spaces which are partitioned into a (possibly infinite) ordered binary tree of subsets.  An example is the partition of the unit interval into dyadic subintervals. The measures are defined on the sigma algebra generated by the binary set system forming the binary partition tree. We define a new class of statistic for these measures, the product coefficients, and use these to formulate a product formula representation theorem and a visualization theorem for these measures. We prove the first theorem and provide notes about the proof of the second deep visualization theorem. We also state and justify a simple rule for inferring product formula representations from samples of measures and a linear convex decision rule for deciding which of two measures a sample is drawn from assuming a multi-scale noise model.  The representation theorem shows that the product coefficient statistics are sufficient to distinguish measures on sigma algebras generated by binary set systems. The visualization theorem shows that measures can be visualized by plane Jordan curves and defines a sub-class of measures for which the Jordan curves distinguish the measures. Since any sigma algebra on a set can be generated by a binary set system, the results apply to all measures. In the first two appendices we describe applications of product coefficient representations to IP network data and LIDAR sensor data. In these applications the product formula parameters, called product coefficients, provide automatically computed features for decision rules. In the third appendix we describe a set of algorithms for computing, analyzing and visualizing  the product coefficient statistics.

The general multi-scale product formula representation for dimension $1$ was first made explicit in the 1991 Annals of Math paper ``The Theory of Weights and the Dirichlet Problem for Elliptic Equations'' authored by R. Fefferman, C. Kenig and J. Pipher \cite{FeKePi91}  (Weights are positive functions.) In this paper the authors were trying to prove that certain weights (``harmonic measures'') arising in elliptic PDE lie in the Coifman Fefferman class $A_\infty$. (For background on the structure of $A_p$ weights see \cite{Jo80}.) They noted that the $A_\infty$ condition holds if and only if the measure is doubling and a certain $L^2$ condition is satisfied for the coefficients. That situation is very far from the case of general measures and in particular the $L^2$ condition they studied does not hold for multifractal measures which typically arise in for many real data sets  including streaming data, images, and videos.

Kolaczyk and Nowak also researched multiscale probability models \cite{KoNo04}.  Their concept was multiscale factorization of given data likelihoods using local conditional probabilities. They identified conditions when multi-resolution analysis of likelihoods are satisfied and showed that the conditions characterize Gaussian, Poisson and multinomial models. They also quantified risk behavior of certain likelihood estimators. 

Recent work by Grebenkov, Beliaev and Jones provides an exposition of L\'{e}vy's formulation of Brownian motion in terms of explicit dyadic multi scale formalisms. They revise  L\'{e}vy's construction of Brownian motion to operate with various Gaussian processes. A Brownian path is explicitly constructed as a linear combination of dyadic ``geometrical features'' at multiple length scales with random weights. Such a representation gives a closed formula mapping of the unit interval onto the functional space of Brownian paths.

Our contribution in this paper is the realization that the product formula representation of measures is true for the very general setting of non-negative measures on sigma algebras generated by binary set systems, that it enables a very general discriminative two-dimensional visualization method for this large class of measures and that it enables new simple quantitative inference and decision rules.

The results here also relate to the field of probabilistic graphical models \cite{KoFr09}.  An ordered binary tree structure on a measure space determines a simple tree-structured probabilistic graphical model.  The product coefficients are differences in conditional probabilities.  The product coefficient representation parametrizes all  tree-structured probabilistic graphical models obtained for a fixed binary tree structure determined by different measures on sigma algebra generated by the binary tree structure and provides canonical product formula representations. The conditional independence conditions are determined by the geometry (i.e., the tree structure). The results thus enable new representation, visualization, inference and decision theorems for these simple tree structured probabilistic, graphical models. It enables sampling from this class, provides noise models, permits comparison across the models in the class and applies to both discrete and continuous spaces. 

\section{The Definition of a Product Coefficient}

Define a binary set system $S$ for a set $X$, to be a  collection $\mathscr{S}$ of subsets $S \subset X$ which form an ordered binary tree rooted at $X$ under the containment relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item $X$ is the root of the tree.
\item Every non-leaf node set $S$ is the disjoint union of its two child sets $L\left(S\right)$ and $R\left(S\right)$.
\end{itemize}
A binary set system need not be finite; some paths from the root may be infinite; finite paths from the root may have different lengths. 

A binary set system $S$ on a measure space $\left(X,\mu\right)$ is assumed to consist of sets measureable with respect to $\mu$. In this case the sets $S \in \mathscr{S}$ of positive measure, at least one of whose child nodes have positive measure, form a sub-tree $\mathscr{S}^{+}_{\mu}$ of sets $S \in \mathscr{S}$. Complete the tree to be binary  by adding child nodes of zero measure.  For each of the non-leaf nodes in $\mathscr{S}^{+}_{\mu}$ we define a product coefficient $a_S$ as the solution to the following equations. 
\begin{eqnarray}
\mu\left(L\left(S\right)\right) &=& \frac{1}{2}\left({1+a_S}\right)\mu\left(S\right) \\
\mu\left(R\left(S\right)\right) &=& \frac{1}{2}\left({1-a_S}\right)\mu\left(S\right)
\end{eqnarray}
For these nodes the product coefficient is the unique solution to:

Note $\left|a_S\right|=1$ only if either $\mu\left(L\left(S\right)\right) = 0$ or $\mu\left(R\left(S\right)\right) = 0$ (but not both).  This zero volume child node of $S$ is a leaf node of $\mathscr{S}^{+}_{\mu}$.  
Each product coefficient is a canonical statistic (aka a feature) for $\mu |_{\sum\left(\mathscr{S}\right)}$, the measure which is the restriction of the measure $\mu$ to the sigma algebra generated by the binary set system. The product coefficients for a single level (scale) of the tree form a canonical vector statistic for the measure $\mu |_{\sum\left(\mathscr{S}\right)}$; these single level (scale) product coefficient vectors can be concatenated across a set of levels (scales) to form other canonical vector statistics. \\
The measure $\mu |_{\sum\left(\mathscr{S}\right)}$ need not be positive, but must be non-negative. Its support is the union of the leaf nodes of $\mathscr{S}^{+}_{\mu}$  with positive measure.

For the first claim \ref{clm:ProdFormRep1}, it suffices to prove the claim for sets $S$ at scale $n+1$. \subsection{Examples of product formula measures}
Examples of product formula measures may be obtained by defining binary set systems on sets $X$ or
measure spaces $\left(X,\mu\right)$.

\subsubsection{Example 1: Product Formula Representation Theorem for Borel measures on $\left[0,1\right]$}
A Borel measure on a topological space $X$ is a measure defined on $\Sigma\left(X\right)$ the sigma
algebra generated by the open sets of $X$, i.e., on sets generated by the operations of countably infinite
unions, countably infinite intersections and complements. For $X = \left[0,1\right]$, the open sets are
open intervals $\left(a,b\right)$.

For $X=\left[0,1\right]$ the infinite collection of dyadic intervals forms a binary set system $\mathscr{D}$. Specifically for $n$ a non-negative integer, define $I\left(n,i\right)$, the $i$-th dyadic
interval of scale $n$, to be the half open interval
$I\left(n,i\right) = \left[i2^{-n},\left(i+1\right)2^{-n}\right)$ for $i=0,1,\ldots,2^n-2$ and the
closed interval $I\left(n,i\right) = \left[i2^{-n},\left(i+1\right)2^{-n}\right]$ for $i=2^n-1$.
In this second case, the right endpoint is $1$. This infinite collection of dyadic intervals collection forms a binary tree: $L\left(I\left(n,i\right)\right) = I\left(n+1,2i\right)$ and
$R\left(I\left(n,i\right)\right) = I\left(n+1,2i+1\right)$. Note that $\mathscr{D}$ generates the
same sigma algebra as the open sets, i.e., $\Sigma\left(X\right) = \Sigma\left(\mathscr{D}\right)$.

The dyadic measure $dy^{\mathscr{S}}$ for the binary set system consisting of dyadic intervals is the restriction to $\Sigma\left(\mathscr{S}\right)$ of the usual Lebesgue measure $ds$ on $\left[0,1\right]$
which measures an interval by its length
\begin{eqnarray}
dx\left(\left(a,b\right)\right) & = & dx\left(\left[a,b\right)\right) \\
& = & dx\left(\left(a,b\right]\right) \\
& = & dx(\left(\left[a,b\right]\right) \\
& = & b - a
\end{eqnarray}
for $a < b$.

Let $\mu$ be any non-negative measure on $\Sigma\left(\mathscr{S}\right)$ (i.e., $mu\left(I\left(n,i\right)\right) > 0$). The Product Formula Representation Theorem thus implies the

\begin{thm}[Product Formula for Borel Measures on the Unit Interval]
If $\mu$ is a non-negative Borel measure on $\left[0,1\right]$ then
$\mu = \prod_{n=0}^{\infty}\prod_{s=0}^{2^n-1}\left(1+a_Ih_I\right)dx$ where the product coefficients
$a_I$ are defined using $\mu$ for the binary set system $\mathscr{D}$ of dyadic intervals 
$I=I\left(n,s\right)$ and $dx$ denotes Lesbegue measure. Any assignment of product coefficients 
$a_I\in\left(-1,1\right)$ determines a unique positive Borel measure on $\left[0,1\right]$; any
assignment of product coefficients $a_I\in\left[-1,1\right]$ satisfying the constraints:
\begin{itemize}
\item
$a_I = 1 \Rightarrow$ the product coefficients for the tree rooted at $R\left(I\right)$ are zero
\item
$a_I = -1 \Rightarrow$ the product coefficients for the tree rooted at $L\left(I\right)$ are zero
\end{itemize}
determines a unique non-negative Borel measure on $\left[0,1\right]$.
\end{thm}

Note that for a dyadic interval $I=I\left(n,s\right)$, with left half $L$ and right half $R$ whose
measure is positive $\mu\left(I\right) > 0$, the product coefficient is simply

\subsubsection{Example 2: Product Formula Theorem for Borel Measures on the unit hypercube}
An analogous theorem holds for Borel measures on higher dimensional unit cubes for each choice of a binary set system $\mathscr{S}$ consisting of dyadic subdivisions of the unit cube. For example, such a binary system can be obtained by successively halving the sets along dimensions $n,n-1,\ldots,1$ and then iterating this process infinitely. There are many other variants of such dyadic sets systems for higher
dimensional cubes.

The product formula representation theorem can also be used to explicitly construct measures.

See \cite{Oi61} for an early paper with basic properties of welding. Recent works of Astala, Jones, Kupiainen
and Saksman \cite{AsKuSaJo11} provides new, probabilistic classes of welding maps that arise in Conformal Field Theory.

An important deep fact in the theory of conformal mappings is: If there exists an $\epsilon > 0$ such that for
any interval $I$ in the circle $S^1$

then $\mu$ is the derivative of a welding map $\Phi$ for a Jordan curve $\Gamma$. Furthermore, the welding map
$\Phi$ is unique in that any other welding map $\hat\Phi$ whose derivative is $\mu$ is the welding map for a
Jordan curve $M\left(\Gamma\right)$ where $M:\mathbb{C}\rightarrow\mathbb{C}$ is a Mobius transformation
$z \rightarrow \frac{az+b}{cz+d}, ad-bc \neq 0$. This is proved by Lars Ahlfors in the original version of his
book ``Lectures on Quasi-Conformal Mappings'' \cite{Ah06}.

\begin{thm}[Measure Visualization]
For a measure $\mu$ on $\Sigma\left(X,\mathscr{S}\right)$, the sigma algebra of a binary set system on $X$,
let $\mu_{S^1}$ denote the measure on $\Sigma\left(S^1,\tilde{\mathscr{D}}\right)$ with the same product
coefficients.
\begin{enumerate}
\item \label{clm:viz1} If $\mu_{S^1}$ is a positive measure represented by a finite product formula (so none of its product coefficients are $\pm 1$), then $\mu_{S^1}$ is the derivative of a welding map $\Phi:S^1\rightarrow S^1$
determined by a Jordan curve $\Gamma$, denoted $\Gamma_{\mu_{S^1}}$, unique up to Mobius transformations.
\item \label{clm:viz2} If $\mu_{S^1}$ is  represented by an infinite product formula, and if the product coefficients for both 
$\mu_{S^1}$ and $\mu_{S^1} \circ \left( \text{rotation by } \frac{2\pi}{3}\right)$ are bounded away from
$\pm 1$, (i.e., if there exists $\epsilon > 0$ such that all product coefficients satisfy $|a_I| \leq 1 - \epsilon$), then $\mu_{S^1}$ is the derivative of a welding map $\Phi:S^1\rightarrow S^1$ determined by a
Jordan curve $\Gamma$, denoted $\Gamma_{\mu_{S^1}}$, unique up to Mobius transformations.
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}[Proof notes]
This is a non-trivial theorem usually proved by using $L^p$ estimates on the Beurling transform which transforms a function $f:\mathbb{C}\rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ by convolving it with the kernel $\frac{1}{\pi z^2}$. This transformation is a bounded operator on the function space $L^p$ for $1<p<\infty$. For $L^2$ the norm
of this operator is 1. The proof is in the original portion of Ahlfors' book ``Lectures on Quasi-Conformal
Mappings'' \cite{Ah06}.
\end{proof}

For some measures represented by an infinite product formula which does not satisfy the condition
\ref{clm:viz2} of the Measure Visualization theorem, there exist multiple non-equivalent welding maps. In fact,
if the Jordan curve in the plane has positive 2D Lebesgue measure (e.g., a Jordan curve which threads through
a Cantor set with positive 2 dimensional Lebesgue measure) then there exist an uncountable number of non-equivalent welding maps. A deep theorem is: given any closed set of positive measure (e.g., the two sphere $S^2$) there exists a quasi-conformal map $f:\mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ that is not a Mobius 
transformation but is holomorphic off a closed set and one-to-one on the closed set. \cite{Ah06}

The visualization theorem applies only to positive measures but it can be used to visualize approximations
of finitely represented non-negative measures (some of whose product coefficients $a_I=\pm 1$), or to 
visualize infinitely represented measures which do not satisfy $|a_I|\leq 1-\epsilon$. One can choose
$\epsilon$ and deform the product coefficients which do not satisfy the inequality to $\pm \left(1-\epsilon \right)$. For example, for finitely represented measures with disconnected support subtrees, this visualization
should still reveal the disconnectedness of the support if $\epsilon$ is chosen small relative to the finite
set of positive product coefficients on the support set.

\begin{thm}[Measure Visualization]
For a measure $\mu$ on $\Sigma\left(X,\mathscr{S}\right)$, the sigma algebra of a binary set system on $X$,
let $\mu_{S^1}$ denote the measure on $\Sigma\left(S^1,\tilde{\mathscr{D}}\right)$ with the same product
coefficients.
\begin{enumerate}
\item \label{clm:viz1} If $\mu_{S^1}$ is a positive measure represented by a finite product formula (so none of its product coefficients are $\pm 1$), then $\mu_{S^1}$ is the derivative of a welding map $\Phi:S^1\rightarrow S^1$
determined by a Jordan curve $\Gamma$, denoted $\Gamma_{\mu_{S^1}}$, unique up to Mobius transformations.
\item \label{clm:viz2} If $\mu_{S^1}$ is  represented by an infinite product formula, and if the product coefficients for both 
$\mu_{S^1}$ and $\mu_{S^1} \circ \left( \text{rotation by } \frac{2\pi}{3}\right)$ are bounded away from
$\pm 1$, (i.e., if there exists $\epsilon > 0$ such that all product coefficients satisfy $|a_I| \leq 1 - \epsilon$), then $\mu_{S^1}$ is the derivative of a welding map $\Phi:S^1\rightarrow S^1$ determined by a
Jordan curve $\Gamma$, denoted $\Gamma_{\mu_{S^1}}$, unique up to Mobius transformations.
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}[Proof notes]
This is a non-trivial theorem usually proved by using $L^p$ estimates on the Beurling transform which transforms a function $f:\mathbb{C}\rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ by convolving it with the kernel $\frac{1}{\pi z^2}$. This transformation is a bounded operator on the function space $L^p$ for $1<p<\infty$. For $L^2$ the norm
of this operator is 1. The proof is in the original portion of Ahlfors' book ``Lectures on Quasi-Conformal
Mappings'' \cite{Ah06}.
\end{proof}

should still reveal the disconnectedness of the support if $\epsilon$ is chosen small relative to the finite

Our goal is to justify the convex linear decision rule assuming a multi-scale noise model. We will first show that the product coefficients for a noisy measure can be computed recursively bottom up.

\subsection{Convex Linear Decision Rule:} 
Given  measures $\mu_1$ and $\mu_2$ on the sigma algebra generated by the finite binary set system $\mathscr{S}$ on the set $X$, 
a multi-scale noise model determined by  noise parameters  ${n}_\sigma=\{ \sigma_S: S \in \mathscr{S}\}$ 
and random variables $\mathscr{Z}= \{ Z_S: S \in \mathscr{S}\}$ in the noise model, 
let $\mathscr{I}_i, i=1,2$ denote the set of intervals $I_S^i= [a_S- sd_S^i, a_S+ sd_Si]$, 
where $sd_S^i$ is an an upper bound to an approximation (for small values of the noise parameters) to the standard deviation of the product coefficients $a_i^{\sigma,z}$ of the noise model measure. 
Let $D_S$ be a linear decision rule for deciding which interval  $I_S^i= [a_S- sd_S^i, a_S+ sd_S^i]$, $i=1,2$  a point in the union of the two intervals belongs to. Then $\{D_s \}$ determines two disjoint convex sets (cubes)  $C_1$ and $C_2$. The convex linear decision rule for deciding which measure best represents the product coefficients computed from a sample $X_S$  is: choose the measure whose convex set $C_i$ is closest to the vector of product coefficients for the sample. (The faces of theses convex sets are aligned with the coordinate planes (in product coefficient space)). 

Note:  The previous lemma shows that such an approximation to the standard deviation can be computed from the product coefficients of the measure and the noise parameters. The intervals can be adjusted to be confidence intervals for each of the measures or can be adjusted to cover more than one standard deviation.  Furthermore, a simpler decision rule can be obtained by selecting only the product coefficients (features) whose ``intervals'' for the two measures overlap.  




\section{Summary}
In this paper we focused on measures defined on spaces which are partitioned into a (possibly infinite) ordered binary tree of subsets.  An example is the partition of the unit interval into dyadic subintervals. The measures are defined on the sigma algebras generated by the binary set system forming the binary partition tree. We defined a new class of statistic for these measures â the product coefficients and use these to formulate and prove a product formula representation theorem. The theorem proves that the statistics are sufficient to uniquely characterize the measures given the tree structure. We present a visualization theorem for these measures. We also stated and justified a simple rule for inferring product formula representations from samples of measures and a linear convex decision rule for deciding which of two measures a sample is drawn from assuming a multi-scale noise model.

The representation theorem shows that the product coefficient statistics are sufficient to distinguish measures on sigma algebras generated by binary set systems. The visualization theorem shows that measures can be visualized by plane Jordan curves and defines a sub-class of measures for which the Jordan curves distinguish the measures. Since any sigma algebra on a set can be generated by a binary set system, the results apply to all measures.

Finite product coefficient representations can be computed for data sets. In the first two appendices we illustrate how product coefficient representations of measurements on IP traffic data and product coefficient representations of three-dimensional LIDAR data can be used as automatically computed features for decision rules. The theory shows that product coefficients are sufficient to distinguish measures. The experiments show their utility in distinguishing measures that arise in real network and sensor data.
